alert.note: Alert for Accomack; Northampton (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wakefield (Eastern Virginia and Southern Maryland)
info.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 16 at 3:07PM EDT until September 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield
info.description: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, a high risk for rip currents. For the Coastal Flood Statement, up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. * WHERE...Accomack and Northampton Counties. * WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Sunday evening. For the Coastal Flood Statement, until 4 PM EDT this afternoon. * IMPACTS...Large breaking waves of 5 to 6 ft will result in dangerous surf conditions and a high risk for rip currents. Shallow flooding is possible in the most vulnerable locations near the waterfront and shoreline. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. SAXIS VA MLLW CATEGORIES - MINOR 4.5 FT, MODERATE 5.5 FT, MAJOR 6.5 FT MHHW CATEGORIES - MINOR 2.0 FT, MODERATE 3.0 FT, MAJOR 4.0 FT TOTAL TOTAL DEPARTURE DAY/TIME TIDE TIDE FROM NORM WAVES FLOOD FT MLLW FT MHHW FT FT IMPACT -------- --------- --------- --------- ------- -------- 16/02 PM 3.8 1.3 1.1 2 NONE 17/02 AM 3.7 1.2 1.2 1 NONE 17/02 PM 4.0 1.5 1.2 1 NONE 18/02 AM 3.1 0.6 0.7 1 NONE 18/03 PM 3.4 0.9 0.6 1 NONE 19/03 AM 2.8 0.3 0.5 2 NONE NASSAWADOX CREEK AT BAYFORD VA MLLW CATEGORIES - info.instruction: Do not drive through flooded roadways. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times. Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases, the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult to return to shore.
